articles.headline: U.S. and Israel Shift Attention to Peace Process
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Obama he would take “concrete steps” on talks with the Palestinians.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Obama he would take “concrete steps” on talks with the Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that he expected direct negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians to begin “well before” a moratorium on settlement construction expired at the end of September, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel pledged to take “concrete steps” in the coming weeks to get the talks moving.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mark Landler

articles.headline: India Expands Role as Drug Producer
articles.snippet: India’s drug industry is on track to grow 13 percent this year, to just over $24 billion in sales.
articles.abstract: India’s drug industry is on track to grow 13 percent this year, to just over $24 billion in sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: HALOL, India  Below an ancient hilltop temple to Kali, the Hindu goddess associated with destruction and change, Sun Pharmaceutical Industries churns out generic versions of cancer drugs and epilepsy medications bound for the United States.

articles.headline: K.K.R. to Start Trading Publicly
articles.snippet: After a previous effort to go public was thwarted by the financial crisis, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company will command a market value of roughly $6 billion.
articles.abstract: After a previous effort to go public was thwarted by the financial crisis, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company will command a market value of roughly $6 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Henry R. Kravis, the dealmaker who symbolized the merger mania of the 1980s and became one of the most powerful figures on Wall Street, is cashing in.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: China Bank I.P.O. Raises $19 Billion
articles.snippet: The Agricultural Bank of China offering may ultimately raise as much as $22 billion, which would make it the largest in history.
articles.abstract: The Agricultural Bank of China offering may ultimately raise as much as $22 billion, which would make it the largest in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  It was established by Mao Zedong for China’s rural peasants. But on Tuesday, the Agricultural Bank of China embraced a capitalist’s dream: it went public.

articles.headline: 5 Ways Congress Can Bolster Growth
articles.snippet: Direct stimulus aside, Congress could help the economy by persuading companies to spend and by lifting trade.
articles.abstract: Direct stimulus aside, Congress could help the economy by persuading companies to spend and by lifting trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the sake of argument, let’s say that the Senate refuses to take the most obvious steps to help the economy.

articles.headline: Arizona Law Causes Split for Border Governors
articles.snippet: For nearly three decades, governors from both sides of the United States-Mexico border have held a conference, but this year, things are uncertain.
articles.abstract: For nearly three decades, governors from both sides of the United States-Mexico border have held a conference, but this year, things are uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  For nearly 30 years, the governors of the states that line both sides of the United States-Mexico border have gathered to celebrate border bonhomie. They issue proclamations and pledges to work together, air grievances and concerns behind closed doors and pose for the cameras in symbolic showings of cooperation.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Fighting $7,000 Fine in Trampling Case
articles.snippet: Federal officials say it is a mystery as to why Wal-Mart is fighting so hard against such a modest fine.
articles.abstract: Federal officials say it is a mystery as to why Wal-Mart is fighting so hard against such a modest fine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores has spent a year and more than a million dollars in legal fees battling a $7,000 fine that federal safety officials assessed after shoppers trampled a Wal-Mart employee to death at a store on Long Island on the day after Thanksgiving in 2008.

articles.headline: East Swelters in Triple Digits; More to Come
articles.snippet: Safety concerns upended the usual routines as a brutal blast of heat covered the Eastern Seaboard on Tuesday, with little relief expected for days to come.
articles.abstract: Safety concerns upended the usual routines as a brutal blast of heat covered the Eastern Seaboard on Tuesday, with little relief expected for days to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  Children at a day camp near here were pulled from the swimming pool once an hour so the lifeguards could plunge in and cool off. Commuter trains in Washington were slowed because of overheating tracks. Horse-racing tracks were closed in Philadelphia and Wilmington, Del.

articles.headline: American Dream Is Elusive for New Generation
articles.snippet: In the Nicholson family, America is not delivering for a grandson as it did for his father and grandfather.
articles.abstract: In the Nicholson family, America is not delivering for a grandson as it did for his father and grandfather.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAFTON, Mass.  After breakfast, his parents left for their jobs, and Scott Nicholson, alone in the house in this comfortable suburb west of Boston, went to his laptop in the living room. He had placed it on a small table that his mother had used for a vase of flowers until her unemployed son found himself reluctantly stuck at home.

articles.headline: Republican Emerges as Obama’s Annoyer-in-Chief
articles.snippet: Every Congress seems to produce a designated pest, and for this White House, he is Representative Darrell Issa.
articles.abstract: Every Congress seems to produce a designated pest, and for this White House, he is Representative Darrell Issa.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As a sign of the pride Representative Darrell Issa takes in annoying the Obama administration, consider his account of a recent exchange with Rahm Emanuel, a former congressman and now the White House chief of staff. In describing the episode  a chance encounter outside the House gym  Mr. Issa smirked and raised his middle finger.

articles.headline: Markets See Biggest Rally Since May
articles.snippet: There is hope — misplaced, some analysts say — that coming earnings reports will show that corporations are weathering the downturn better.
articles.abstract: There is hope — misplaced, some analysts say — that coming earnings reports will show that corporations are weathering the downturn better.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a day, at least, Wall Street got its groove back.

articles.headline: Steps Point to Possible Swap of Spy Suspects With Russia
articles.snippet: A jailed Russian convicted of spying for the United States has been moved in preparation for a possible trade involving Russian spy suspects detained in the United States.
articles.abstract: A jailed Russian convicted of spying for the United States has been moved in preparation for a possible trade involving Russian spy suspects detained in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Just days after the F.B.I.’s sensational dismantling of a Russian spy ring, the American and Russian authorities on Wednesday were negotiating an exchange of some or all of the 10 accused agents for prisoners held in Russia, including a scientist convicted of spying for the United States.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Scott Shane and Benjamin Weiser
